posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked:
Built a bumper of pretty standard construction. 18mm Baltic Birch Plywood, about 31 inches on a side, 4.5 tall, aluminum corner brackets, noodles, and cordura. Couple of small aluminum brackets to mount to the robot. Came out super nice. Bumper weight came in at 17lbs. Limit is 15 lbs. Super annoying and unfortunate thing to have to redo at competition. But, I‚Äôll take the blame, it‚Äôs our own fault for not weighing them prior. I just assumed they would be under the limit because they were made typical. 2lbs is a ton to take out, it‚Äôs a total rebuild. I have no idea how teams with 5" y‚Äôall bumper wood are making the weight, they must be using lower density wood.

Limits prior to 2020 were 20lbs. The interesting thing is bumpers made prior to kickoff are legal, but apparently only if they meet the current spec.

TLDR: Weigh your bumpers, and I think the limit should be higher. Give us 20lb on the bumpers and put the robot back to 120lbs.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
Weird, when using 18-19mm birch and steel corner brackets I pretty reliably hit 12.5-13.5 pounds with fairly heavy mounts as well.

I suspect your issue is the 22mm wood‚Ä¶ Is that even legal?
Definitely seems odd. With 3/4 plywood, steel corner brackets, and beefy aluminum mounts, we were still at 13 lb.

posts.name: Ravi Ponmalai
posts.cooked:
I guess it depends on how much heavy lifting the ‚Äú~‚Äù in ‚Äú~19mm‚Äù is doing.

From the rules: ‚Äúbe backed by ¬æ in. thick (nominal, ~19mm) by 5 in. ¬± ¬Ω in. (~127 mm ¬± 12.7 mm) tall plywood, Oriented Strand Board (OSB) or solid wood (with the exception of balsa).‚Äù

22mm seems like a lot over (0.86in vs the specified 0.75in)

posts.name: John Hascall (he)
posts.cooked: That plywood must be insanely dense.  We use pine, solid noodles, and Andymark fabric.  Our bumpers (27"x30" robot) are 10.4 lbs.  This includes a 25.5" length of 1x1" 1/8" square tube along the front for extra impact resistance.

posts.name: sanddrag
posts.cooked: Sorry, I meant 18mm. Edited.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked:
Can you post pictures and cross sections?

Your weight makes even less sense now.

We were at 15.1 lbs at Utah on one set last week, 14.9 on the other set. 18mm Baltic, steel corners. Had to cut away the pretty tape off the back to get to weight. There were a LOT of teams with overweight bumpers there who had to rebuild on the spot. This is a pretty major concern for me this year.

posts.name: Stewart Riley
posts.cooked: That must be really heavy plywood or your using really stout corner brackets. We‚Äôre using 3/4" solid poplar (4 1/2" wide) and steel mounting brackets with dacron sailcloth covers and only come in at 12.5lbs. Of course, we use glued and screwed finger-jointed corners, so no corner brackets to add weight (and they‚Äôre more than strong enough.)

Plywood is quite a bit denser than solid woods like Pine and Poplar. White Oak is an example of a solid wood that is denser than Baltic Birch ply, and is also going to split on you, so I‚Äôd say don‚Äôt use that, but density varies between species and even from board to board and tree to tree.

Generally good quality Baltic ply and marine grade ply are going to be dense and consistent, and because the grain orientation runs perpendicular throughout there are no weaknesses due to grain. Here are some photos of the destruction of our bumpers from the Utah Regional last week. The steel corners were bent and the solid core noodles are broken and pulverized, but the plywood is perfectly fine and can be reused.

posts.name: Troy Dietz
posts.cooked:
anon91718515:

Had to cut away the pretty tape off the back to get to weight.

Pro tip: spray paint is much lighter than tape and does this same job quite well

posts.name: Christine Low
posts.cooked:
31" to a side‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs a BIG robot.

Plywood height should be 5" +/- 0.5", so at 4.5" you are running at the minimum height legally possible.

What kind of mounting hardware are you using?  How many screws/nuts/bolts?  What kind of pool noodles? How much tape?

We‚Äôre 27" square frame, 4 5/8" tall plywood, and we‚Äôre barely hitting 10 pounds per bumper.  Adding steel corner brackets + screws adds 9.4 oz.

Trying to figure out how you got that heavy??

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
sanddrag:

Limits prior to 2020 were 20lbs.

The bumper weight came down 5 lb while the robot weight went up equally.  The other weight correlated change was that compressors were required to be on-board. Added: I certainly don‚Äôt want to see robot total weight go up any.  Moving up to 5 pounds back to the bumpers, or combining the weights sounds like a good idea.  Maybe even lighter overall.

posts.name: chrisrin
posts.cooked:
The only time I recall our bumpers being overweight was a few years ago when the bumper crew found & decided to use some really thick gauge full height brackets. (Like pounds of brackets.) And then they forgot to weigh the bumpers before competition.

Thanks goodness for the volunteer machine shop people! They helped us get the brackets trimmed down enough that the bumpers made weight.

Still, as the OP says, you don‚Äôt want to be in that situation, so weigh your bumpers well before competition.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
Like Mr Noble said, Baltic Birch is heavy stuff my plywood standards I think we are at about 13lbs of bumper with a 24x28 frame perimeter, 4.6" high backing, no corner brackets and only 2 mounting brackets. So baltic birch might not be doable for those with large frame perimeters.

On the plus side, we recently test ran the robot into the corner of the subwoofer at max speed (19ft/sec), and the bumper and single thin wall 2x1 frame tube were completely undamaged.

Red oak, 25x30, 5.5 tall was 15 lbs for us with steel corners and no fabric or noodle.  Hoping that cutting down to 5 inches gets it for us.  We had bumper problems last year with failure, now I‚Äôm regretting the red oak.  Didn‚Äôt even know there was a bumper weight in the past.  Now I‚Äôm sweating it out at the last minute.

posts.name: Totally out of touch
posts.cooked: @sanddrag now that the dust has settled, can you share pics of your bumpers? Still really curious about this

posts.name: Richard Wallace
posts.cooked:
Overpowered robots are swerving about at ludicrous speeds!  We need stronger bumpers, not lighter ones.

Let‚Äôs add a checklist item to bumper inspection: LRI wearing steel-toed boots gives your robot a good swift kick in the bumper!

posts.name: Brendan Simons, 5406
posts.cooked:
Our bumpers were 14.9lb at the Durham College Event.  The 1/8" full-wrap aluminum sheet metal bracket attached is 7lb of that, and the plywood is another ~7lb.   The 2.5" solid pool noodles and fabric weighted about a pound together. Flat pattern of cx24-bumper sheet metal (1).pdf (310.5 KB)

Despite being over built, our robot‚Äôs frame was still damaged due to a mid field collision.  I‚Äôm with @Richard_Wallace - bumpers have to get heavier, or robots have to get slower!

posts.name: Cory Walters
posts.cooked: Third option is build robust robots/frames. Forth option is all of the above.
